metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (an observation system of meteorological elements gradient of Daman superstation, 2018)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2018. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (AV-14TH;3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5, 10, 15, 20, 30, and 40 m, towards north), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 2.5 m, 8 m in west of tower), four-component radiometer (PIR&PSP; 12 m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (IRTC3; 12 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (LI190SB; 12 m, towards south, vertically upward; another four photosynthetically active radiation, PQS-1; two above the plants (12 m) and two below the plants (0.3 m), towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward), soil heat flux (HFP01SC; 3 duplicates with G1 below the vegetation; G2 and G3 between plants, -0.06 m), a TCAV averaging soil thermocouple probe (TCAV; -0.02, -0.04 m), soil temperature profile (AV-10T; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, Ta_10 m, Ta_15 m, Ta_20 m, Ta_30 m, and Ta_40 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, RH_10 m, RH_15 m, RH_20 m, RH_30 m, and RH_40 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, Ws_10 m, Ws_15 m, Ws_20 m, Ws_30 m, and Ws_40 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m, WD_10 m, WD_15 m, WD_20 m, WD_30m, and WD_40 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) (μmol/ (s m-2)), average soil temperature (TCAV, ℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, below the vegetation; Gs_2, and Gs_3, between plants) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content), above the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_U_up and PAR_U_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), and below the plants photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day.The meterological data during September 17 and November 7 and TCAV data after November 7 were wrong because the malfunction of datalogger. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2018-6-10 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid agricultural areas using the eddy covariance system?
Definition.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid agricultural areas using the eddy covariance system is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure with respect to available energy. Errors in surface-air temperature differences and classification errors in component temperatures can lead to uncertainties in flux estimations. Additionally, the strong advective environment in these regions can exacerbate these challenges, affecting the accuracy of flux measurements such as sensible and latent heat fluxes.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'oasis–desert system' refer to in the context of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies?
Definition.Answer: The term 'oasis–desert system' refers to the unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas where oases are surrounded by deserts. These systems are crucial for maintaining ecological stability and agricultural productivity in such regions. Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems is important for achieving ecological security and sustainable development, as they play a significant role in the regional and global carbon cycles.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the Daman superstation compare to those used in other oasis–desert systems in terms of capturing soil and canopy component temperatures?
Comparison.Answer: The Daman superstation uses a combination of meteorological measurements and a high-resolution thermal camera to capture soil and canopy component temperatures, while other oasis–desert systems utilize eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the challenges faced in estimating evapotranspiration in arid agricultural areas compared to oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Both arid agricultural areas and oasis–desert ecosystems face challenges related to heterogeneous landscapes and measurement errors. However, arid agricultural areas specifically struggle with advective conditions affecting flux measurements, while oasis–desert ecosystems contend with broader ecological degradation issues and the balance of carbon exchange.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of multisource observational data enhance the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of various data sources such as eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations provides comprehensive measurements of turbulent fluxes, hydrometeorological parameters, and soil and vegetation characteristics. This multi-faceted approach can improve the accuracy and depth of understanding regarding the interactions of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these ecosystems, offering insights into ecological stability and socioeconomic impacts.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can long-term observational datasets contribute to the sustainable development of oasis–desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Long-term datasets capturing energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with hydrometeorological and soil parameters, offer critical insights into the ecological dynamics of oasis–desert systems. These datasets enable researchers to understand and monitor the balance between oasis and desert systems, helping to maintain ecological stability, support sustainable agricultural practices, and contribute to carbon neutrality goals in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for rigorous data quality control when collecting meteorological and surface process data in the Heihe River Basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Factors contributing to the need for rigorous data quality control include the complexity of the surface heterogeneity, data loss due to equipment failures such as the data collector issues, the presence of environmental elements that may affect sensor readings, and the need to maintain a high frequency of data collection (every 10 minutes) to ensure temporal accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to estimate evapotranspiration accurately in irrigated agricultural areas using models like the TSEB?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Estimating evapotranspiration accurately is challenging due to the strong advective conditions in irrigated areas, which can affect the surface-air temperature difference, and the errors in determining soil and vegetation temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures. These challenges can lead to inaccuracies in component temperature calculations and subsequent energy balance estimations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential challenges and outcomes arise from implementing long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems for carbon and water vapor exchange studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems presents challenges such as data management, quality control, and accounting for ecological variability. However, it results in valuable insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, supporting ecological stability and sustainable development in these regions. Such datasets are crucial for understanding oasis–desert interactions and informing policies for carbon neutrality and ecological security.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it essential to use meteorological and hydrometeorological data collected from multiple station setups for understanding oasis–desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development. Long-term observations from multiple stations provide a quantitative understanding of these exchanges, which is essential to achieving carbon neutrality and ecological security in arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals are pursued by employing the TSEB model with soil and canopy component temperatures to estimate evapotranspiration in irrigated agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to achieve better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimations using soil and canopy component temperatures. This approach aims to improve the accuracy of ET measurements, which can be crucial for water resource management and understanding the water cycle in heterogeneous landscapes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting long-term data on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to gain insights into the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange within these ecosystems. This understanding supports the ecological security and sustainable development of oases, providing necessary data for recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting the ecological stability of these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are utilized to integrate ground-based measurements with remote sensing data for comprehensive evapotranspiration analysis in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Comprehensive evapotranspiration analysis in heterogeneous landscapes involves integrating ground-based measurements with remote sensing data by using models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. Ground measurements, such as meteorological parameters and soil heat fluxes, are combined with high-resolution thermal images to calculate soil and canopy component temperatures. The data are processed to partition evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration fractions, which are then validated using stable isotope techniques and eddy covariance system measurements.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, obtained via a high-resolution thermal camera, enable the accurate partitioning of evapotranspiration into evaporation and transpiration. These temperatures are then used as inputs to a two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, which is validated with eddy covariance system measurements and stable isotope techniques.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in thermal imaging contribute to the separation of soil and canopy temperatures in agricultural research?
Enablement.Answer: Thermal infrared cameras, such as the Fluke Ti55, are manually operated on platforms to capture thermal radiation images of cropland. These images help in classifying soil and canopy pixels using methods like the maximum-likelihood method, which in turn allows for the extraction of soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures, enhancing the separation of these temperatures for research.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques are essential for ensuring the quality and accuracy of long-term hydrometeorological data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques include the collection, processing, and archiving of data from various sources like eddy covariance systems, scintillometers, and automatic weather stations. Quality control involves ensuring data completeness, removing duplicate records, and eliminating data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, with specific handling for missing or questionable data points.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods in arid and semi-arid regions face challenges in accurately measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in such areas are facing ecological degradation issues like drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, and intensified land desertification, which complicate data collection efforts.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in achieving accurate data collection for soil and canopy temperatures in strongly advective agricultural areas?
Expectation.Answer: The uncertainty in surface-air temperature differences and errors in determining component temperatures from composite radiometric temperatures are significant challenges, especially in strongly advective environments.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be difficulties in separating soil and canopy latent heat fluxes in data collection methods over heterogeneous landscapes?
Expectation.Answer: The separation is challenging due to image classification errors that misidentify soil and vegetation pixels, affecting canopy temperature estimates, and the uncertainties in estimating incoming short- and long-wave radiation through the canopy.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of data collection methods employed for measuring soil and canopy temperatures in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: The methods used for measuring soil and canopy temperatures in oasis–desert ecosystems appear to be effective as they involve high-resolution thermal cameras and thermal infrared technology. This ensures precise temperature readings necessary for modeling evapotranspiration processes in arid regions. However, limitations exist due to image classification errors, especially with varying vegetation abundance, which could affect the accuracy of temperature estimations.

Judgmental.Question: What are the primary challenges identified in collecting reliable data for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges in collecting reliable data in oasis–desert areas include ecological degradation such as drying up of rivers and lakes, natural vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors can complicate long-term data collection efforts and impact the quality and reliability of the data collected.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how data quality control is effectively maintained in the collection of meteorological data over a year-long period.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality control in the collection of meteorological data is maintained through several measures: ensuring consistent data points daily (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with a specific indicator, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceeds physical or instrument limits, and uniformly formatting date and time.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about what methodologies are used for accurately estimating soil and vegetation component temperatures in complex ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Accurately estimating soil and vegetation component temperatures involves using thermal infrared cameras to obtain soil and canopy component temperatures, classifying visible and NIR images into soil and canopy pixels, and converting thermal infrared temperatures to radiation temperatures by considering incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems and propose solutions based on current data collection practices.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges include dealing with heterogeneous landscapes and the complex interaction between soil and vegetation. Current practices involve using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, which might face issues like energy balance closure. Solutions could include enhancing ground-based measurements with satellite data and improving the separation of soil and vegetation signals through advanced imaging techniques.
